children.text: Complete guide to using and developing with Adonis EOS â€” a modern, headless CMS built with AdonisJS, React, and PostgreSQL.
Perfect for non-technical users who create and manage content:
Technical documentation for developers and system administrators:
- How to approach upgrades and maintenance

<!-- Coming Soon:
- Post Types - Defining custom content types
- Forms & Submissions - Frontend form handling
- Webhooks - Event-driven integrations
- Import/Export - Content portability
- Database Schema - Tables and relationships
- Services & Actions - Business logic organization
- RBAC System - Role-based access control
- Performance & Caching - Optimization strategies
-->
Adonis EOS is a modern, headless CMS that combines:
Build pages with reusable components. Each module is self-contained and configurable.
Four default roles with granular permissions:
Create content in multiple languages with locale-specific URLs, menus, and translations.
Upload images with automatic variant generation, dark mode support, and optimization.
Extensible agent system for content enhancement, SEO optimization, and automated workflows.

# Install and setup
npm install
cp .env.example .env
node ace migration:run
node ace db:seed

# Start development
npm run dev
Welcome! This guide will help you get started creating and managing content in Adonis EOS.
You'll be taken to the Dashboard
The dashboard shows all your content in one place:
: All pages, blog posts, and other content
: Find content by title or slug
: Filter by type, status, or locale
: Button to start a new post
Select a post type (Page, Blog, etc.)
: The main heading for your content
: Click "Add Module" to add content blocks:
: Rich text editor for paragraphs and formatting
: Large banner with image and call-to-action
: Work in progress, not visible publicly
: Ready for approval by Editor Admin
Modules are like building blocks for your content:
: Drag the handle (â‰¡) to move modules up or down
: Prevent accidental changes to important modules
Each module has different fields depending on its type. The editor will show you exactly what you can customize.
Depending on your role, you'll have different publishing options:
An Editor Admin will review and approve your changes
Create, edit, and publish content directly
Review and approve content from other editors
Switch to your target language in the editor
for tips on each content type
Learn how to create and manage content in Adonis EOS.
You'll see the dashboard with content overview
Modules are content blocks that make up your page.
Click a module to add it
Click on any module to expand it
Lock important modules to prevent accidental deletion
In a module with an image field
Choose from library or upload new
Images have multiple sizes automatically generated:
Dark mode variants can be created for automatic theme switching.
You cannot publish directly. Use this workflow:
General website pages (About, Contact, Services, etc.)
Articles with publication dates, categories, and taxonomies
Use the search and filters to find content:
Create a "template" page and duplicate it for consistency.
Save commonly used module configurations by duplicating posts.
Always save as draft first, review, then publish.
Use the preview feature to see how content looks before going live.
Add alt text to all images
Use semantic heading levels (H1 â†’ H2 â†’ H3)
Upload light and dark logo versions
Use Blog List module on main blog page
Contact your administrator for permission issues
Adonis EOS uses a file-based Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) system for granular permissions management.
âœ… Publish and delete any content
âœ… Approve reviews and AI reviews
âŒ Manage users or system settings
Perfect for content managers who need publishing power.
Ideal for content creators who need review before publishing.
Permissions follow a hierarchical naming pattern:

{section}.{action}

Examples:
- posts.create
- posts.edit
- posts.publish
- posts.delete
- media.upload
- media.delete
- admin.settings.view
- admin.settings.update

import type { RoleDefinition } from '#types/role_types'

const contentManagerRole: RoleDefinition = {
  name: 'content_manager',
  label: 'Content Manager',
  description: 'Manages content with publishing rights',
  
  permissions: [
    // Content
    'posts.create',
    'posts.edit',
    'posts.view',
    'posts.publish',
    'posts.delete',
    'posts.review.approve',
    
    // Media
    'media.upload',
    'media.view',
    'media.edit',
    'media.delete',
    
    // Menus & Forms
    'menus.view',
    'menus.edit',
    'forms.view',
    'forms.edit',
    
    // Admin access
    'admin.access',
  ],
}

export default contentManagerRole
The role is automatically registered on server startup from
Select the new role from dropdown
: Restart server to register new role files
: Check exact permission key spelling and role name
All actions are logged with user and role information:
Learn how to collaborate with your team using the review system.
Adonis EOS has a three-tier review system to ensure content quality:
Open a post in the editor
Make your changes in the main editing area
Your changes are saved to the Review draft (not live)
An Editor Admin will be notified to review your work
Look at the tabs at the top of the editor:
Switch between tabs to compare what's live vs. what you've submitted for review.
Once an Editor Admin approves your review:
You can start working on new changes
Open a post that has pending reviews
You can make additional edits if needed
If AI agents are configured, you may see an
to move them to the Review tab
Make manual adjustments in Review mode
: If your CMS has a comments feature, explain significant changes
: Review your own work before sending for approval
: Ensure meta titles and descriptions are optimized
: Verify all URLs and CTAs work correctly
View past versions in the "Revisions" panel
See who made changes and when
Revert to a previous version if needed
Revisions are kept for a configurable retention period
Q: Can I edit published content?
A: Yes! Edit the Approved version and click "Save Changes" to update live content immediately (Editor Admins only). Or save for review to have changes approved first.
Q: What happens if I accidentally save changes?
A: Use the Revisions panel to revert to a previous version.
Q: Can I have multiple people review the same post?
A: Yes, but only one Review draft exists at a time. Coordinate with your team to avoid overwriting each other's work.
Q: How do I know if a post needs review?
A: The dashboard shows review status for each post. Look for the "Review" badge.
Learn how to upload, organize, and use images and files in your content.
or drag files into the upload area
Select one or more files from your computer
Files are uploaded and processed automatically
When editing a module that requires an image:
Choose from existing media or upload new files
Select the image you want to use
Check with your administrator for file size limits and specific format requirements.
When you upload an image, the system automatically creates variants:
The system chooses the appropriate variant based on where the image is used, ensuring fast page loads.
Some images may look better with different versions for light and dark modes:
Upload your light mode image normally
In the media editor, upload a dark mode variant
The system automatically shows the correct version based on the user's theme
This is optional but recommended for logos and hero images.
Create folders to organize your media
Always add alt text to images:
Provides context if images fail to load
Click the image icon in the rich text editor
Adjust size and alignment as needed
Specific image modules (Hero Banner, Gallery, etc.) have dedicated image selectors:
Some post types have custom image fields:
Upload the highest quality version you have
Recommended minimum width: 1600px for hero images, 800px for content images
Only upload images you have permission to use
Add credits in the description field when needed (used as the visual caption)
Write descriptive alt text (not just "image" or the filename)
Describe what the image shows, not just what it is
For decorative images, you can leave alt text empty
Click on any media item in the library
Update alt text, title, or description (caption)
: Deleting media removes it from all posts where it's used!
The system warns you if the media is in use
Media not used in any posts
Old media that can be cleaned up
Ask your administrator if this feature is available.
Q: Why is my image blurry?
A: Upload a higher resolution version. The system scales down but can't scale up effectively.
A: Video support depends on your configuration. Ask your administrator.
Q: How do I change an image that's already in a post?
A: Edit the post, find the module with the image, and click "Select Media" to choose a different image.
Q: What's the maximum file size?
A: This varies by configuration. Typically 10MB for images. Large files may be rejected or take longer to upload.
Learn how to create and manage multi-language content.
Your CMS supports multiple languages (locales). Common examples:
Each post can have translations in multiple locales.
Open the post you want to translate
Look for the language switcher in the header
You'll be redirected to a new post editor with:
A link to the original post
In the post list, find the post you want to translate
: Adapt for the target language and culture
: Translate all prose, headings, and text
: Meta titles and descriptions should be translated
: Usually leave as-is for consistency, or adapt minimally
: External links typically stay the same
Use the same modules in the same order
Match the layout and design of the original
Ensure images and media are appropriate for all locales
Translations are automatically linked when you create them through the editor. The system tracks:
Users can switch between languages on the public site, and the system shows the corresponding translation.
: Translations are independent. Changing the original doesn't automatically update translations.
âœ… Can view and edit existing posts
âœ… Can create and edit translations
âŒ Cannot create new posts from scratch (except translations)
âŒ Cannot publish directly (must go through review)
Each translation gets its own URL:
The URL pattern depends on your system configuration.
Create separate menu structures for each language
Search engines index each translation separately:
Translate slugs when appropriate for SEO
Identify key content to translate first:
Announce the new language to your audience
Keep them in sync with the original
Decide if you need separate translations
Most systems treat these as separate locales
Consider creating one and adapting as needed
Some systems remember previously translated phrases:
Some configurations integrate with translation APIs:
Best used as a starting point, not final content
Q: Do I need to translate every field?
A: Translate all user-facing text. Technical fields (slugs, IDs) often stay the same.
Q: Can I delete a translation?
A: Yes (if you have permission), but the original post remains. Deleting a translation doesn't delete the original.
Q: What if I don't finish a translation?
A: Save as Draft and continue later. Incomplete translations aren't visible publicly.
Q: How do I know which posts need translation?
A: Check the dashboard for translation status indicators or ask your administrator for a translation report.
A detailed guide to each type of content module available in the system.
Modules are reusable content blocks that you assemble to build pages. Think of them like LEGO bricksâ€”each one does something specific, and you combine them to create complete pages.
: Reorder by dragging up or down
: Open the module editor to change content
: Remove the module from the page
: Rich text content with paragraphs, headings, lists, and formatting.
: Rich text editor with formatting tools
Use headings (H2, H3) to structure content
Add links by selecting text and clicking the link icon
: Large, attention-grabbing banner at the top of a page.
Test readability on different screen sizes
: Prominent button or link to drive user action.
Make CTAs stand out with contrasting colors
Limit to 1-2 CTAs per screen for focus
: Display multiple images in a grid or slideshow.
Use images with similar aspect ratios for clean grids
: Collapsible sections for FAQs or detailed information.
Use for secondary information users may skip
Order items logically (often by importance or frequency)
: Collect user input (contact forms, surveys, etc.)
Keep forms shortâ€”only ask for essential information
Test form submissions before going live
: Embed external content (videos, maps, social media)
Consider privacy implications of third-party embeds
Editing affects all posts using it
Best for repeated elements (headers, footers, CTAs)
: Be careful editing global modulesâ€”changes appear everywhere they're used!
Some systems let you save module combinations as templates:
Reuse the structure for new posts
: Guide users to the next action
: Ensure modules work on small screens
: Ensure interactive modules work without a mouse
: Build a library of working patterns
: For elements that should be consistent
Q: Can I create custom modules?
A: Contact your developer or administrator. Custom modules require development work.
Q: Why can't I edit a module?
A: It might be locked. Look for a lock icon and unlock it first. Or you may not have permission.
Q: Can I copy modules between posts?
A: Some systems support this. Look for "Copy Module" or "Duplicate" actions. Or use templates.
Q: What's the difference between a module and a block?
A: They're the same thing! "Module" and "block" are often used interchangeably.
, a modern headless CMS built with AdonisJS and React.

Adonis EOS is a full-featured content management system designed for developers who need flexibility, performance, and modern tooling. It combines the power of AdonisJS on the backend with React/Inertia.js on the frontend.
: Build pages with reusable, customizable modules
: Granular permissions for different user roles
: Advanced image handling with variants and dark mode support
: Flexible content types (pages, blog posts, profiles, companies)
: Extensible AI agent system for content enhancement
: Create custom forms with submissions tracking
: Dynamic navigation menus with nested items
: Secure draft sharing with token-based previews
Before working with Adonis EOS, you should have a solid understanding of:
Adonis EOS follows the Model-View-Controller (MVC) pattern. Familiarity with MVC concepts will help you understand how the application is structured:
: Represent your database tables and handle data logic
: Handle the presentation layer (React components via Inertia.js)
: Process requests and coordinate between models and views
. We recommend reviewing the following topics in the
: For bridging the backend and frontend

# Clone the repository
git clone <your-repo-url>
cd adonis-eos

# Install dependencies
npm install

# Configure environment
cp .env.example .env

# Run migrations
node ace migration:run

# Seed initial data
node ace db:seed

# Start development server
npm run dev
After seeding, you'll have these accounts:

adonis-eos/
â”œâ”€â”€ app/                    # Backend application code
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ controllers/        # Route handlers
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ models/            # Database models
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ services/          # Business logic
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ modules/           # CMS module definitions
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ roles/             # RBAC role definitions
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ agents/            # AI agent definitions
â”œâ”€â”€ inertia/               # Frontend React code
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ pages/             # Page components
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ components/        # Reusable components
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ modules/           # Frontend module components
â”œâ”€â”€ database/
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ migrations/        # Database schema
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ seeders/          # Seed data
â”œâ”€â”€ docs/                  # Documentation
â””â”€â”€ public/               # Static assets
The Adonis EOS API provides RESTful endpoints for managing content, media, and settings.
Most API endpoints require authentication via session cookies. Admin-level access requires the
- Post type (page, blog, profile, company, testimonial)
Returns full post data including modules, metadata, and relationships.
Soft deletes the post (can be restored).

POST /api/media/upload
Content-Type: multipart/form-data

file: <binary>
alt_text: "Description"
categories: ["hero", "featured"]
Generates image variants (light or dark theme).
Lists media assets with optional filtering.
Returns all modules for a post with their current props.
Adonis EOS can trigger webhooks on various events:
API endpoints are rate-limited to prevent abuse:
Modules are the building blocks of content in Adonis EOS. Each module is a reusable component with configurable properties.
) â€“ schema, configuration, and rendering mode
) â€“ the UI component (static or React)
) â€“ register with the module registry
suffixes. Whether a module is static or React is controlled entirely by
value in your backend module config
â€¦the system will find and render your component automatically. You
Your module is now available in the admin!
: Module is instance-specific to a post
: Module is reusable across multiple posts
Mark props as translatable for i18n support:
Limit module to specific post types:
Test your module in the admin:

A centralized design system that lets you customize all colors across the admin panel and public site with minimal configuration. Changes apply automatically to all components including Sonner toasts, forms, cards, and more.

âœ… All admin pages (dashboard, post editor, etc.)
âœ… All site pages (homepage, post views, etc.)
âœ… Sonner toast notifications
âœ… All form components
âœ… Cards, modals, dialogs
âœ… Buttons and links
âœ… Borders and dividers
âœ… Automatically adapts to light/dark mode
â†’ Admin theme (indigo + slate by default)
Everything else â†’ Site theme (violet + stone by default)
Adonis EOS uses a design token system built on Tailwind CSS for consistent, customizable theming.

--backdrop-low      /* Light backgrounds */
--backdrop-medium   /* Medium backgrounds */
--backdrop-high     /* Elevated surfaces */
--line             /* Borders and dividers */

--neutral-low      /* Subtle text */
--neutral-medium   /* Body text */
--neutral-high     /* Headings */

--standout         /* Primary actions */
--on-standout      /* Text on standout */

--accent           /* Secondary actions */
--on-accent        /* Text on accent */
These tokens are available as Tailwind classes:

Heading

Body text
Dark mode is automatically handled via CSS custom properties. The system adapts based on
Images can have separate dark mode versions:

# .env
MEDIA_DARK_BRIGHTNESS=0.8  # 0-1, lower = darker
MEDIA_DARK_SATURATION=0.7  # 0-1, lower = desaturated

Sans-serif heading

Serif quote
Monospace code
Upload light and dark logos in
Logos are automatically swapped based on theme.
for both light and dark modes

// âœ… DO: Use the simplified tokens (Tailwind color names backed by CSS vars)

Title

Description

// âŒ DON'T: Hardcode specific colors or numbered classes

# 1. View admin theme
http://localhost:3333/admin

# 2. View site theme  
http://localhost:3333/

# 3. Toggle dark mode (browser console)
localStorage.setItem('theme-mode', 'dark')
location.reload()

localStorage.setItem('theme-mode', 'light')
location.reload()
Both support automatic light/dark mode and can be changed instantly by editing one file!
Configure SEO settings, URL patterns, and redirects for optimal search engine visibility and user experience.
Adonis EOS provides comprehensive SEO and routing features:
: Custom URL structures per post type and locale
: Automatic generation of meta tags, Open Graph, Twitter Cards
Define custom URL structures for different post types:
: Each page should have a unique meta title
: Use canonical tags to prevent duplicate content
: Add descriptive alt text to all images
: All content is responsive by default
SEO settings can be configured at:
Access SEO tools from the Admin panel:
Post Editor â†’ SEO Settings - Per-post SEO
Learn more about internationalization and how to manage multi-language content with proper hreflang implementation.
Adonis EOS provides comprehensive multi-language support for global content delivery.
Create translations by creating new posts with:
Mark props as translatable in module schema:

/welcome              â†’ Default locale (en)
/es/bienvenido        â†’ Spanish version
/fr/bienvenue         â†’ French version

GET /api/menus/primary?locale=en  â†’ English menu
GET /api/menus/primary?locale=es  â†’ Spanish menu
Create the original content in the default locale (usually
Once reviewed, publish the translated version.
To find all translations of a post:
Returns all locale versions of posts with that slug.
- Fall back to default locale if translation missing
Create separate form definitions per locale.
: Content not showing in new locale
: Ensure post exists with correct locale value
: Create locale-specific menu or verify API call includes
: Check role has appropriate permissions in role configuration
Learn how to create, organize, and manage content in Adonis EOS. This section covers posts, modules, templates, and custom fields.
Adonis EOS uses a flexible content management system built around:
: The core content unit (pages, blog posts, profiles, etc.)
: Reusable content blocks that make up posts
: Pre-configured module layouts for rapid post creation
Post types define different kinds of content with specific configurations:
Modules are the building blocks of content. They can be:
: Editable but cannot be removed (when seeded from templates)
Create a post (optionally from a template)
Explore the detailed Content Management guide to learn about creating posts, managing modules, and using templates effectively.
Extensible AI agent system for automated content workflows, SEO optimization, and integrations with external services like n8n.
Agents are file-based definitions that can:
Run manually from the post editor dropdown
Trigger automatically on specific events (publish, review, etc.)
Integrate with external services via webhooks
Webhook-based agents that call external services:
Future support for in-process AI services.

import type { AgentDefinition } from '#types/agent_types'

const SeoOptimizerAgent: AgentDefinition = {
  id: 'seo-optimizer',
  name: 'SEO Optimizer',
  description: 'Automatically generates and optimizes SEO metadata',
  type: 'external',
  enabled: true,

  external: {
    url: process.env.AGENT_SEO_OPTIMIZER_URL || '',
    devUrl: process.env.AGENT_SEO_OPTIMIZER_DEV_URL,
    secret: process.env.AGENT_SEO_OPTIMIZER_SECRET,
    timeout: 30000,
  },

  scopes: [
    { scope: 'dropdown', order: 20, enabled: true },
    { scope: 'post.publish', order: 10, enabled: false },
  ],
}

export default SeoOptimizerAgent
Agents can be triggered in different contexts:
Agents receive the canonical post JSON format:
only, not live content. Users review before publishing.
Agent suggestions appear in Review mode
Agents configured with event scopes run automatically:
When a post is published, this agent runs automatically.
Multiple agents on the same scope execute in order:
Add Response node with optimized JSON
Review AI suggestions in Review mode
Switch to Review tab to see changes
Check agent response format matches expected schema
Complete guide to deploying Adonis EOS to production environments.

# Application
NODE_ENV=production
PORT=3333
HOST=0.0.0.0
APP_KEY=<generate with: node ace generate:key>
APP_NAME=Adonis EOS

# Database
DB_HOST=localhost
DB_PORT=5432
DB_USER=your_user
DB_PASSWORD=your_secure_password
DB_DATABASE=adonis_eos

# Session
SESSION_DRIVER=cookie

# Redis (recommended for production)
REDIS_HOST=localhost
REDIS_PORT=6379
REDIS_PASSWORD=your_redis_password

# Cache
CACHE_DRIVER=redis  # or 'database' if Redis not available

# Security
CSRF_ENABLED=true

# Rate Limiting
RATE_LIMIT_ENABLED=true
RATE_LIMIT_STORE=redis  # or 'memory'

# Generate APP_KEY
node ace generate:key

# Generate webhook secret
openssl rand -hex 32

# Production migration (requires confirmation)
node ace migration:run --force

# Seed users, roles, and initial content
node ace db:seed --force
Change the default admin password immediately after first login!

# Start
pm2 start ecosystem.config.cjs

# Save process list
pm2 save

# Setup startup script
pm2 startup

# View logs
pm2 logs adonis-eos

# Monitor
pm2 monit

# Restart
pm2 restart adonis-eos

# Stop
pm2 stop adonis-eos

[Unit]
Description=Adonis EOS
After=network.target postgresql.service redis.service

[Service]
Type=simple
User=www-data
WorkingDirectory=/var/www/adonis-eos
Environment=NODE_ENV=production
ExecStart=/usr/bin/node build/bin/server.js
Restart=on-failure
RestartSec=10

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target

# Reload systemd
sudo systemctl daemon-reload

# Enable service
sudo systemctl enable adonis-eos

# Start service
sudo systemctl start adonis-eos

# Check status
sudo systemctl status adonis-eos

# View logs
sudo journalctl -u adonis-eos -f

# Add buildpack
heroku buildpacks:add heroku/nodejs

# Add PostgreSQL
heroku addons:create heroku-postgresql:mini

# Add Redis
heroku addons:create heroku-redis:mini

# Set environment variables
heroku config:set NODE_ENV=production
heroku config:set APP_KEY=$(openssl rand -hex 32)

# Deploy
git push heroku main

# Run migrations
heroku run node ace migration:run --force

# Seed database
heroku run node ace db:seed --force
Set up SSL with Let's Encrypt
Coming soon - Docker and Docker Compose configurations.

# Create backup
pg_dump -U username -d adonis_eos -F c -f backup_$(date +%Y%m%d_%H%M%S).dump

# Restore backup
pg_restore -U username -d adonis_eos -c backup_20250101_120000.dump

#!/bin/bash
DATE=$(date +%Y%m%d_%H%M%S)
BACKUP_DIR="/backups/adonis-eos"
mkdir -p $BACKUP_DIR

# Database backup
pg_dump -U dbuser -d adonis_eos -F c -f $BACKUP_DIR/db_$DATE.dump

# Media files backup
tar -czf $BACKUP_DIR/media_$DATE.tar.gz /var/www/adonis-eos/public/uploads

# Keep only last 30 days
find $BACKUP_DIR -name "*.dump" -mtime +30 -delete
find $BACKUP_DIR -name "*.tar.gz" -mtime +30 -delete

# PM2 logs
pm2 logs adonis-eos

# systemd logs
journalctl -u adonis-eos -f
Add health check endpoint for monitoring:

# Allow SSH, HTTP, HTTPS
sudo ufw allow 22/tcp
sudo ufw allow 80/tcp
sudo ufw allow 443/tcp
sudo ufw enable

# Install certbot
sudo apt-get install certbot python3-certbot-nginx

# Obtain certificate
sudo certbot --nginx -d yourdomain.com

# Auto-renewal
sudo certbot renew --dry-run

# Check logs
pm2 logs adonis-eos

# Check environment
node ace env:check

# Verify database connection
psql -U username -d adonis_eos -c "SELECT 1"

# Monitor memory
pm2 monit

# Set max memory restart
pm2 restart adonis-eos --max-memory-restart 1G
Adonis EOS follows the same philosophy as
, not a plugin. That means the codebase is expected to be
owned and maintained by your engineering team
no built-in CMS UI for updating the core
. Updates are applied the same way you would update any other AdonisJS app:
Review upstream changes (AdonisJS, dependencies, and this repo if you forked it).
Run migrations, tests, and smoke tests.
Deploy through your existing CI/CD pipeline.
This keeps the operational model simple and predictable, and avoids surprising changes being pushed into production without review.
The project structure, configuration, and providers closely follow AdonisJS conventions so that:
Framework upgrades feel familiar if you already know AdonisJS.
You can rely on the official AdonisJS documentation and ecosystem when evolving the app.
New team members with AdonisJS experience can onboard quickly.
Your team is responsible for the lifecycle of this application:
Watch AdonisJS and key dependency changelogs.
Track your own forkâ€™s changes if you diverge from upstream EOS.
Use feature branches / PRs for upgrades.
Validate critical flows (admin, publishing, webhooks) in staging.
Plan and execute rollbacks if needed.
environments; apply upgrades to staging first.
and bump them intentionally with a short review of release notes.
Pull latest changes from your main branch or upstream.
Run migrations in a safe environment.
Run automated tests and smoke tests.
Deploy to staging, verify, then promote to production.
Have a clear rollback strategy (revert commit, rollback DB if needed).
Treat this repository like any other
in your stack: changes should be deliberate, reviewed, and deployed through your normal engineering processes rather than via in-app buttons.

props.title: A Node.js-first CMS starter for product teams
props.subtitle: Adonis EOS is an AdonisJS + Inertia + React starter that treats content modeling, modules, and performance as first-class concerns. It feels like a modern page builder, but lives entirely in your Node.js stack.

props.title: Why Adonis EOS?

features.title: Modular Architecture
features.description: Build pages with reusable, composable modules. Create custom modules with our intuitive API and node ace commands.

features.title: Multi-Language Support
features.description: Built-in internationalization with locale-specific content, URL patterns, and translation workflows.

features.title: Role-Based Access Control
features.description: Fine-grained permissions system with customizable roles for admins, editors, and translators.

features.title: Content Workflows
features.description: Review drafts, AI-assisted content, and approval workflows to ensure quality before publishing.

features.title: Fully Customizable
features.description: Tailwind CSS theming, custom post types, taxonomies, and extensible module system.

features.title: Developer Friendly
features.description: Built on AdonisJS with TypeScript, Inertia.js, and React. Clean API, great DX, and comprehensive documentation.

props.subtitle: Built for modern Node.js development with everything you need out of the box

props.title: Explore the Module Catalog
props.subtitle: This page is a working gallery of content modules used across the EOS starter. Designers can inspect layout and typography; editors can see what each module can do before using it in real content.

props.title: Hero with Media
props.subtitle: Two-column hero with media and dual CTAs. Uses project-neutral color tokens.

children.text: Use this section to preview how long-form content will look when authored with the rich text editor. Designers can validate typography, spacing, and rhythm; editors can explore headings, lists, code snippets, and more.

Below is a bulleted list followed by a numbered list. This is useful for checklists, feature breakdowns, and stepâ€‘byâ€‘step instructions.
Typographic scale for headings and body copy
Comfortable line length and spacing for readability
Support for inline emphasis such as bold and italic text
Draft your content in the editor.
Add structure with headings, lists, and quotes.
Use inline code and code blocks for technical details.
to show how emphasis is rendered in the final layout.
You can also include links, for example to the

Designers can use this sample to inspect heading sizes, spacing between elements, and how longâ€‘form content flows on different breakpoints. Editors can experiment with the Lexical toolbar to reproduce these patterns in their own posts.

props.title: Kitchen Sink Demo

children.text: This is a rich text field powered by Lexical, shown inside the Kitchen Sink example.

props.description: Demonstration of all supported field types, including media.

images.caption: Sample gallery image one from the Module Catalog demo.
Sample gallery image two from the Module Catalog demo.
Sample gallery image three from the Module Catalog demo.

props.title: Built for growing teams and ambitious roadmaps

features.body: Streamline launch checklists, approvals, and handoffs so cross-functional teams can ship in days, not weeks.
features.title: Launch faster

features.body: Codify your best practices into repeatable workflows that every team can follow.
features.title: Standardize playbooks

features.body: Give marketing, sales, and operations a shared view of what ships next.
features.title: Align stakeholders

props.subtitle: Use this expanded layout to tell a longer story about major phases, advantages, or pillars of your product.

props.body: This layout pairs narrative content with a focused visual, ideal for feature callouts, product explainers, and lightweight storytelling.
props.title: Let's create more tools and ideas that bring us together.

plans.name: Starter
plans.description: Best option for personal use & for your next project.

plans.name: Company
plans.description: Relevant for multiple users, extended & premium support.

plans.name: Enterprise
plans.description: Best for large scale uses and extended redistribution rights.

props.title: Designed for business teams like yours
props.subtitle: We focus on markets where technology, innovation, and capital can unlock long-term value and drive economic growth.

items.answer: You will have access to download the full design source, including all of the pages, reusable components, responsive variants, and supporting illustrations.
items.question: What do you mean by â€œFigma assetsâ€?

items.answer: Once you purchase a license you can use the product for as long as you like and receive all future updates at no additional cost.
items.question: What does â€œlifetime accessâ€ mean?

items.answer: Support is provided directly by the authors of the product so you get highâ€‘quality, contextâ€‘aware answers.
items.question: How does support work?

items.answer: Yes. Your license covers an unlimited number of internal or client projects, as long as you are not reselling the kit itself as a competing product.
items.question: Can I use this for multiple projects?

items.answer: Free updates include new components, patterns, and improvements that we ship as part of the public roadmap for this product.
items.question: What do â€œfree updatesâ€ include?

items.answer: In most cases you can use the kit in openâ€‘source projects, as long as the project is not a direct replacement for this product (for example, a competing UI kit or pageâ€‘builder).
items.question: Can I use this in openâ€‘source projects?

props.title: Frequently asked questions
props.subtitle: Answers to common questions about how we work, what is included, and how we support your team.

props.quote: Flowbite is just awesome. It contains tons of predesigned components and pages starting from login screen to complex dashboard. Perfect choice for your next SaaS application.

props.title: Meet the Team
props.subtitle: Profiles are powered by the Profile post type. Add or edit profiles in the CMS and they will appear here automatically.

props.title: Testimonials
props.subtitle: Showcase customer feedback using the Testimonial post type. Add or edit testimonials in the CMS and they will appear here automatically.

props.title: Our Blog
props.subtitle: We use an agile approach to test assumptions and connect with the needs of your audience early and often.

props.title: Youâ€™ll be in good company
props.subtitle: Logos and names of customers or partners, managed via the Company post type.

props.title: Contact us
props.subtitle: Fill out the form and our team will get back to you shortly.

props.body: Use this section to invite visitors to reach out. The form will appear alongside this copy.
props.title: Ready to talk?
props.successMessage: Thanks! Your message has been sent.

post_custom_field_values.value: I'm speechless with how easy this was to integrate within my application. If you care for your time, I hands down would go with this.
FlowBite provides a robust set of design tokens and components based on Tailwind CSS, giving a solid foundation for any project.
Everything is so well structured and simple to use. The well designed components are beautiful and will level up your next application.
This is a code-first test author bio

posts.title: Content Management
posts.excerpt: Learn how to create and manage content in Adonis EOS.

posts.title: Documentation
posts.excerpt: Complete guide to using and developing with Adonis EOS â€” a modern, headless CMS built with AdonisJS, React, and PostgreSQL.

posts.title: For Editors
posts.excerpt: Welcome! This guide will help you get started creating and managing content in Adonis EOS.

posts.title: Roles & Permissions
posts.excerpt: Adonis EOS uses a file-based Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) system for granular permissions management.

posts.title: Review Workflow
posts.excerpt: Learn how to collaborate with your team using the review system.

posts.title: Managing Media
posts.excerpt: Learn how to upload, organize, and use images and files in your content.

posts.title: Working with Translations
posts.excerpt: Learn how to create and manage multi-language content.

posts.title: Working with Modules
posts.excerpt: A detailed guide to each type of content module available in the system.

posts.title: For Developers
posts.excerpt: Welcome to **Adonis EOS**, a modern headless CMS built with AdonisJS and React.

posts.title: API Reference
posts.excerpt: The Adonis EOS API provides RESTful endpoints for managing content, media, and settings.

posts.title: Building Modules
posts.excerpt: Modules are the building blocks of content in Adonis EOS. Each module is a reusable component with configurable properties.

posts.title: Theming System
posts.excerpt: A centralized design system that lets you customize all colors across the admin panel and public site with minimal configuration. Changes apply automatically to all components including Sonner toasts, forms, cards, and more.

posts.title: SEO & Routing
posts.excerpt: Configure SEO settings, URL patterns, and redirects for optimal search engine visibility and user experience.

posts.title: Internationalization (i18n)
posts.excerpt: Adonis EOS provides comprehensive multi-language support for global content delivery.

posts.title: Content Management Overview
posts.excerpt: Learn how to create, organize, and manage content in Adonis EOS. This section covers posts, modules, templates, and custom fields.

posts.title: AI Agents
posts.excerpt: Extensible AI agent system for automated content workflows, SEO optimization, and integrations with external services like n8n.

posts.title: Deployment Guide
posts.excerpt: Complete guide to deploying Adonis EOS to production environments.

posts.title: Update Philosophy
posts.excerpt: Adonis EOS follows the same philosophy as **AdonisJS** itself: this is a **full application**, not a plugin. That means the codebase is expected to be **owned and maintained by your engineering team** over time.

posts.title: Home
posts.meta_description: Adonis EOS is a Node.js-first CMS starter built on AdonisJS, Inertia, and React. Model content with modules, keep everything in your TypeScript codebase, and ship fast with a modern editorial experience.

posts.title: Module Catalog
posts.excerpt: Showcase of all content modules with sample configurations.
posts.meta_description: Showcase of all content modules for design and QA.

posts.title: Ada Lovelace
posts.excerpt: Mathematician and writer, often regarded as the first computer programmer.

posts.title: Alan Turing
posts.excerpt: Pioneer of theoretical computer science and artificial intelligence.

posts.title: Grace Hopper
posts.excerpt: Computer scientist and US Navy rear admiral, known for work on compilers.

posts.title: Acme Inc.
posts.excerpt: Fictional company used for demos and examples.

posts.title: Umbrella Corp.
posts.excerpt: Global conglomerate featured in fictional case studies.

posts.title: Wayne Enterprises
posts.excerpt: Large multinational with a diverse R&D portfolio.

posts.title: Pricing
posts.excerpt: Adonis EOS is open source and free to use under the Apache 2.0 license.
posts.meta_title: Adonis EOS Pricing - Open Source & Free
posts.meta_description: There is no license fee for Adonis EOS. It is 100% open source under the Apache 2.0 license, ready to run in your own infrastructure.

templates.name: documentation-default
templates.description: Default template for documentation pages with breadcrumb and reading progress
